entry.et: Middle English everich, every, from Old English ǣfre ǣlc, from ǣfre ever + ǣlc each

def.dt: :being each individual or part of a group without exception
:being each in a series or succession every few days every once in a while
:being all taken severally
:being each within a range of possibilities was given every chance
:complete entire we have every confidence in her
:at intervals :occasionally

entry.et: probably by folk etymology from Middle English everich way every way

def.dt: :in every direction
:in a disorderly manner :irregularly toys scattered about every which way

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German hant hand

def.dt: :the terminal part of the vertebrate forelimb when modified (as in humans) as a grasping organ
:the forelimb segment (as the terminal section of a bird's wing) of a vertebrate higher than the fishes that corresponds to the hand irrespective of its form or functional specialization
:a part serving the function of or resembling a hand: as
:the hind foot of an ape
:the chela of a crustacean
:something resembling a hand: as
:an indicator or pointer on a dialect the hands of a clock
:index 5
:a cluster of bananas developed from a single flower group
:a branched rootstock of ginger
:a bunch of large leaves (as of tobacco) tied together usually with another leaf
:personal possession usually used in plural the documents fell into the hands of the enemy
:control supervision usually used in plural left the matter in her hands
:side direction men fighting on either hand
:one of two sides or aspects of an issue or argument on the one hand we can appeal for peace, and on the other, declare war
:a pledge especially of betrothal or bestowal in marriage
:style of penmanship :handwriting wrote in a fancy hand
:signature
:skill ability tried her hand at sailing
:an instrumental part had a hand in the victory
:a unit of measure equal to 4 inches (10.2 centimeters) used especially for the height of horses
:assistance or aid especially involving physical effort lend a hand
:participation interest had no hand in the decision
:a round of applause
:a player in a card game or board game
:the cards or pieces held by a player
:a single round in a game
:the force or solidity of one's position (as in negotiations) trying to strengthen their hand
:a person who performs or executes a particular work two portraits by the same hand
:a person employed at manual labor or general tasks a ranch hand
:worker employee employed over a hundred hands
:a member of a ship's crew all hands on deck
:a person skilled in a particular action or pursuit
:a specialist or veteran in a usually designated activity or region a China hand
:handiwork doings
:style of execution :workmanship the hand of a master
:the feel of or tactile reaction to something (as silk or leather)
:a punch made with a specified hand knocked him out with a good right hand
:near in time or place :within reach use whatever ingredients are at hand
:currently receiving or deserving attention the business at hand
:by or through the action of
:with the hands or a hand-worked implement (as a tool or pen) rather than with a machine
:from one individual directly to another deliver the document by hand
:in one's possession or control had matters well in hand with money in hand
:in preparation
:under consideration
:everywhere
:in present possession or readily available kept supplies on hand
:about to appear :pending
:in attendance :present
:in one's possession or care too much time on my hands
:without delay or deliberation
:in a summary or peremptory manner rejected the plan out of hand
:done with :finished
:out of control
:with the hands fruit eaten out of hand
:into possession the letter … has come to hand George Washington
:within reach

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English ynce, from Latin uncia ounce

def.dt: :a unit of length equal to 1/36 yard see weight table
:a small amount, distance, or degree is like cutting a dog's tail off by inches Milton Friedman
:stature height
:a fall (as of rain or snow) sufficient to cover a surface or to fill a gauge to the depth of one inch
:a degree of atmospheric or other pressure sufficient to balance the weight of a column of liquid (as mercury) one inch high in a barometer or manometer
:a small advantage especially from lenient or compassionate treatment usually used in the phrase give an inch
:to the utmost degree looks every inch a winner
:very gradually or slowly
:almost to the point of came within an inch of succeeding

entry.et: Middle English (Scots), from Scottish Gaelic innis

def.dt: :island

entry.et: Middle English; partly from Anglo-French tur, tourn turning, circuit (from turner to turn); partly from Middle English turnen to turn

def.dt: :the action or an act of turning about a center or axis :revolution rotation
:any of various rotating or pivoting movements in dancing or gymnastics
:the action or an act of giving or taking a different direction :change of course or posture an illegal left turn: as
:a drill maneuver in which troops in mass formation change direction without preserving alignment
:any of various shifts of direction in skiing
:an interruption of a curve in figure skating
:deflection deviation
:the action or an act of turning so as to face in the opposite direction :reversal of posture or course an about turn the turn of the tide
:a change effected by turning over to another side a turn of the cards
:a place at which something turns, turns off, or turns back :bend curve
:a short trip out and back or round about took a turn through the park
:an act or deed affecting another especially when incidental or unexpected one good turn deserves another
:a period of action or activity :go spell took a turn at the piano
:a place, time, or opportunity accorded an individual or unit of a series in simple succession or in a scheduled order waiting her turn in line
:a period or tour of duty :shift
:a short act or piece (as for a variety show)
:public appearance :performance makes frequent guest star turns
:an event in any gambling game after which bets are settled
:the order of the last three cards in faro used in the phrase call the turn
:something that revolves around a center: as
:lathe
:a catch or latch for a cupboard or cabinet door operated by turning a handle
:a musical ornament consisting of a group of four or more notes that wind about the principal note by including the notes next above and next below
:a special purpose or requirement used chiefly in the phrase serve one's turn
:an act of changing :alteration modification a nasty turn in the weather
:a change in tendency, trend, or drift hoped for a turn in his luck a turn for the better an unexpected turn of events
:the beginning of a new period of time :the time when one period changes to the next the turn of the century
:distinctive quality or character
:a fashioning of language or arrangement of words :manner of expression skillful turns of phrase
:the shape or mold in which something is fashioned :cast
:the state or manner of being coiled or twisted
:a single round (as of rope passed about an object or of wire wound on a core)
:natural or special ability or aptitude :bent inclination a turn for logic an optimistic turn of mind
:a special twist, construction, or interpretation gave the old yarn a new turn
:a disordering spell or attack (as of illness, faintness, or dizziness)
:a nervous start or shock snuck up on her and gave her quite a turn
:a complete transaction involving a purchase and sale of securities
:a profit from such a transaction
:turnover 7b
:something turned or to be turned: as
:a character or slug inverted in setting type
:a piece of type placed bottom up
:on every occasion :continually they opposed her at every turn
:one after another in regular succession
:variously alternately a book that is by turns pedantic, delightful, and infuriating
:in due order of succession
:at the point of turning tide is on the turn
:not in due order of succession play out of turn
:at a wrong time or place and usually imprudently talking out of turn
:to perfection
